options.label: D
options.text: An ice cube forms when water vapor is cooled, while a snowflake forms when water vapor turns directly into ice.

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: What are the universal human rights? - Benedetta Berti

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the concept of human rights?

options.label: A
options.text: Human rights are privileges granted by governments.

options.label: B
options.text: Human rights are universal, inalienable, and apply to all individuals regardless of their background or circumstances.

options.label: C
options.text: Human rights are only applicable to specific groups of people.

options.label: D
options.text: Human rights are not recognized by international law.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main purpose of the United Nations when it was created?

options.label: B
options.text: To reaffirm faith in fundamental human rights and promote peace and security.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the document that lays the basis for modern international human rights law?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The European Convention on Human Rights.

options.label: C
options.text: The principle of freedom from torture or slavery.

options.label: D
options.text: The principle of freedom of expression.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between negative freedoms and positive freedoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Negative freedoms are the right to freedom of expression and religion, while positive freedoms are the right to freedom of movement and residence.

options.label: B
options.text: Negative freedoms are the freedom from torture or slavery, while positive freedoms are the freedom of expression and religion.

options.label: C
options.text: Negative freedoms are the right to life and liberty, while positive freedoms are the right to education and occupation.

options.label: D
options.text: Negative freedoms are the right to freedom of movement and residence, while positive freedoms are the right to life and liberty.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem in enforcing human rights universally?

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The European Convention on Human Rights is not effective.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main criticism of the Universal Human Rights Laws?

options.label: A
options.text: They are not effective in enforcing human rights.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They are not recognized by international law.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not applicable to specific groups of people.

multiple-choice.question: What is the positive role of Universal Human Rights Laws?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: They are not effective in enforcing human rights.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not recognized by international law.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Can you solve the prisoner hat riddle? - Alex Gendler

options.label: C
options.text: To solve a mathematical problem and prove their intelligence

options.text: If at least nine of them guess correctly

options.label: C
options.text: If all of them guess correctly

options.label: D
options.text: If none of them guess correctly

multiple-choice.question: What is the solution proposed by the individuals to guarantee their survival?

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: They realize that they can communicate with each other

options.label: C
options.text: They realize that they can use the parity (odd or even) of the number of hats they see to deduce the color of their own hat

options.label: D
options.text: They realize that they can use the total number of hats they see to deduce the color of their own hat

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They have a 50% chance of giving a wrong answer about their own hat

options.label: C
options.text: They always give a correct answer about their own hat

options.text: They never give an answer about their own hat

options.label: C
options.text: They don't know the color of their own hat

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: They look for a total number of hats of the specified color

options.label: D
options.text: They look for a random number of hats of the specified color

options.label: C
options.text: They don't know the color of their own hat

options.label: D
options.text: They are confused and can't deduce the color of their own hat

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It guarantees their survival with 50% probability

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: They may lead to a more democratic society

options.label: C

According to the transcript, what is unique about human language compared to animal communication?

options.label: C
options.text: Human language has a powerful combination of grammar and productivity

options.label: D
options.text: Human language is only used for food-related topics

title: The ancient origins of the Olympics - Armand D'Angour

title: Can you solve the bridge riddle? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: How long does it take for the zombies to catch up to the group?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the narrator is too slow

options.label: B
options.text: Because the lab assistant is too slow

options.label: C
options.text: Because the bridge can only hold two people at a time

options.label: D

title: How smart are dolphins? - Lori Marino

multiple-choice.question: What event in 1985 is often cited as an example of dolphin mimicry?

options.label: A
options.text: A dolphin pretending to be Poseidon and then throwing a seaweed garland into the ocean

options.label: B
options.text: A dolphin swimming alongside a ship

options.label: C
options.text: A dolphin playing with a seaweed garland

options.label: D
options.text: A dolphin performing tricks for food

multiple-choice.question: Which group of cetaceans is characterized by smaller teeth and larger brains?
What is the term for the brain size compared to the average for a cetacean's body size?
What is an example of a sophisticated form of cooperation exhibited by dolphins in Florida?

options.label: A
options.text: Hunting fish in a group, where one dolphin kicks up mud while another gives the signal for the other dolphins to line up and catch the escaping fish

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the dolphin group off the Australian coast that has learned to use sponges to protect their rostrums?
What is the term for the ability to recognize oneself in a mirror?
What is an example of a study that demonstrates dolphins' ability to recognize their own thoughts?

options.label: A
options.text: A study on dolphin metacognition, where dolphins comparing two sounds could indicate a same, different, or uncertain response

options.label: B
options.text: A study on dolphin social behavior

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a dolphin behavior that demonstrates empathy and altruism?
Why do humans still hunt dolphins for meat, endanger them through fishing and pollution, or imprison them to perform tricks?

options.label: A
options.text: Because humans cannot empathize with dolphins enough to keep them safe and free

options.label: B
options.text: Because dolphins are not intelligent and complex beings

options.label: C
options.text: Because dolphins are not social animals

options.label: D
options.text: Because dolphins are not capable of complex behaviors

options.label: A
options.text: Whether dolphins are intelligent and complex beings

options.label: B
options.text: Whether humans can empathize with dolphins enough to keep them safe and free

options.label: D
options.text: Whether dolphins are capable of complex behaviors

title: How false news can spread - Noah Tavlin

multiple-choice.question: Who is often attributed to the quote "A lie can travel halfway around the world while the truth is putting on its shoes"?
What is the term for when publication A publishes misinformation, publication B reprints it, and publication A then cites B as the source for the information?
What phenomenon occurs when multiple publications report on the same initial piece of false information, making it appear as though it has been verified by multiple sources?
In what year was a pseudoscientific paper published arguing that routine vaccination of children causes autism?
What is the name of the disease that has been virtually eradicated in the United States, but is now being contracted by deliberately unvaccinated children?
What type of content can make it harder to debunk information, as it can be referenced in published articles and later used as a citation?
What is the name of the journal that published a satirical article on energy expenditure in adolescents playing new generation computer games?

options.label: B
options.text: The New England Journal of Medicine

options.label: D
options.text: The Journal of the American Medical Association

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon that occurs when a joke article is formatted to resemble a real one and is picked up by outlets not in on the joke?
What can be done to slow down a lie and give the truth more time to put on its shoes?

options.label: B
options.text: Searching for criticisms of suspicious information

options.label: C
options.text: Tracing the original source of a report

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of our desire for quick answers overpowering our desire to be certain of their validity, multiplied by billions of people around the world?
